author: mikekasprzak
title: Crafting game with MANY tokens
description: Can you build a game that exists entirely on the blockchain? How can we get users more comfortable with tokens and smart contracts?

assessments.note: The idea behind the proposal is good I understand it as something minecraft like with finite ressource. The proposer says he has to watch his ideas not to get out of control. It still happened a little. It is hard to tell how this game is gonna be able to scale. But a game does always bring a good network effect to a ecosystem.

The proposer effectively addresses the challenge by outlining a game that would bring users into the Cardano ecosystem. The usage of tokens in the way described would be an interesting use case to see how this is handled by a wallet's UI (i.e. would you need some way to filter the various tokens per project). The game that is described is something that I would definitely be interested in playing and have no doubt that it would similarly attract others as well.

A well designed NFT game could successfully onboard new participants in the Cardano Ecosystem.  The proposer claims to have extensive experience in the gaming industry which would benefit the design and marketing of the product.
This could be a good idea, but it lacks details on how it would actually be implemented and linked to the Cardano blockchain.
assessments.reply: I'll admit my proposal is far from perfect, but I feel like this reviewer may have either quit reading early, or is simply unfamilair with Metamask and existing Web3 ecosystem of other blockchains

assessments.note: The proposal aims to increase the types of tokens used by a single app (both fungible and non-fungible) and have a mechanism to encourage daily use of those tokens. The type of application proposed has the potential of encouraging a dedicated following.  In addition, this proposal has the opportunity to solve challenges that could be of benefit to the Cardano community as a whole.
While the details are missing, the concept - if properly implemented - could accelerate adoption.

The proposer has 20+ years experience in the gaming industry which helps a lot. But there is no mention of experience in the blockchain area. Then such a game uses a lot of time to develop and the proposer is working alone, maybe searching for a team would help.

A more detailed plan and budget is missing unfortunately.
Can you give an example of one of the games you have created?

Given the proposer's experience as a game developer, it seems very likely that they will be able to accomplish what is outlined in the proposal. The budget seems reasonable for a programmer and an artist to get the "base" game completed. It would be helpful to add time estimates as well.  The proposer also identifies several risks and challenges that would need to be addressed such as the cost of transactions, a browser wallet solution similar to metamask, and user identities.

feasibility: 2/5
The proposer does not present a clear time-line for development although smart contract will certainly be required to execute the product. The real costs/transaction volumes required to play would have a dramatic impact on the attractiveness of gameplay. The proposer needs to provide a more granular and detailed description of the gameplay to demonstrate their understanding of how such a game would function on the block chain.  Once the funding has been used up, how will the project remain sustainable?
No technical details. This is an idea, not a concrete proposal.
assessments.reply: I'm not convinced they read the proposal fully.

assessments.note: The proposer identified their experience but without any details. The existing Cardano transaction fees may make popularity traction more difficult based on the proposals design. The proposal identified that it could not be played until another proposal is built.

The proposer asks many valid questions and raises concerns and dependencies (e.g. web wallets). The proposal gives a general direction and makes connection to the game development experience, but it is not clear how the lack of particular blockchain experience impacts the success of this proposal. Since an artist will be hired, a detailed breakdown of the budget would warrant a higher score.

The proposal helps to get an understanding of the idea of the project. Unfortunately it misses a clear roadmap, technical details on how the proposer is going to try to achieve his goals and it misses more informations about the proposer. You can always add a linkedin account or link old projects

As you discussed, I think transaction fees will be a limiting factor, unless the game uses Babel fees where SPOs accept your token as the transaction fee. It might be better to keep most of the game off-chain and only have trading of completed item NFTs on-chain. I'm very hopeful for the success of your project, but I think you might need to make more progress with ideas before getting funding. Long-term funding is key to the success of this kind of game. How would you ensure the longevity of the project?

The proposer provides a very clear scope for the game they are proposing, as well as additional features to explore for possible future additions to the game. Breaking these down into stages would be helpful in determining the feasibility of the project; does the proposer plan to add the additional features in future challenges?

The proposer provides no auditable goals on which to audit the success of the project. If funding was received, how many NFT artworks would be commissioned? How rich of a game world can we expect for the 12,000 dollar funding? How will gameplay provide revenue to the developer to make the project sustainable?

Please provide technical details on where the game itself will reside (I assume centralised), what platforms it will be played on, how it will actually interreact with the blockchain (is it just storing NFT's of in game items?) and how it will be marketed?
assessments.reply: What's decentralized and what's not is covered. Again I'll admit my proposal is lacking, but short of including it in the title, the proposal is literally about using the blockchain as a datastore for a web game.

assessments.note: The proposal is well described. It would be helpful for voters to see a potential timeline. It should also be noted whether the second planet (post end-game) would require additional funding.
No metrics for success (most likely due to the lack of clear vision for this first version) is provided. The proposer has also not outlined how progress can be analyzed b stakeholders.

solution: Building a "simple" crafting game with dozens of tokens. Collect different resource tokens daily, refine them, make tools, things, and trade
experience: 20+ year professional in the game industry. I've lead and shipped more than a dozen games. I also run a popular game jam community and event
